{{color box|#500000}} {{color box|#C2B280}} |website = [http://www.txstate.edu www.txstate.edu] |logo=[[File:Texas State UniversityâSan Marcos Logo.svg|center|200px]] |footnotes = }} '''Texas State UniversityâSan Marcos''' (informally '''Texas State University''', or simply '''Texas State''', it discourages the use of ''TSU''{{cite web |url=http://www.umktg.txstate.edu/resources/guides/editorial-styleguide/ed-guide-t.html |title=Editorial Style Guide |accessdate=2008-11-27}}) is a doctoral-granting university located in [[San Marcos, Texas]]. In fall 2011, the university had a record-high enrollment of 34,113 students. It is the largest institution in the [[Texas State University System]], the [[List of largest Texas universities by enrollment|sixth-largest]] university in [[Texas]], and one of the fifty-five largest universities in the United States.{{cite web |url=http://www.umktg.txstate.edu/resources/facts.html |title=Texas State Facts |publisher=Institutional Research, Texas State University |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} For the 2009-2010 year, Texas State University was considered a top producer of [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]] Fellows when two students became beneficiaries of research grants under the [[Fulbright Program]].{{cite web |url=http://us.fulbrightonline.org/documents/Chronicles/chronicle_ma_09.pdf |title=Fulbright Recipients - Universities (Masters) |publisher=Fulbright |accessdate=October 22, 2009 }} Texas State joined three other universities in its category to have all applicants receive fellowships.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2009/10/FulbrightHonor102109.html |title=Texas State a "Top Producer" of Fulbright Fellows |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=October 22, 2009 }} ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' lists Texas State as a Regional University. In [[U.S. News & World Report]]'s Best Colleges 2011 Texas State ranked 40th among all Regional Universities in the West and tied for 12th among western public Regional Universities.{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/san-marcos-tx/texas-state-university-3615 |title=Best Colleges |publisher=US News and World Report |accessdate=August 26, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/san-marcos-tx/texas-state-university-3615 |title=Texas State University Profile |publisher=US News and World Report |accessdate=August 26, 2010}} Texas State is also the lead school of a multi-institution teaching center offering undergraduate and graduate programs at the [[Round Rock Higher Education Center]] (RRHEC) in the greater north [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] area. Additionally, the main campus in San Marcos serves as the location of the fictional school TMU (Texas Methodist University) in the [[NBC]] TV series ''[[Friday Night Lights (TV series)|Friday Night Lights]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstatebobcats.com/genrel/040307aaa.html |title=Lights, Camera & Action |publisher=txstatebobcats.com |date=April 7, 2007 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} In addition, the University is accredited by the [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] (SACS). Texas State University is the only university in the state to have a former [[President of the United States]] as an alumnus. President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] graduated from what was then Southwest Texas State Teachers College in 1930 with a teaching certificate and a Bachelor of Science in history. In 1965, he returned to Southwest Texas State College, as the school was known then, to sign the [[Higher Education Act of 1965]].{{cite press release |url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2005/08/LBJStatue082605.html |title=Regents agree to statue honoring LBJ at Texas State |publisher=Texas State University |date=August 26, 2005 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} ==History== The bill to establish '''Southwest Texas State Normal School''' in San Marcos was first proposed on March 3, 1899 by Fred Cocke, representing the 98th Texas House District. Texas State Senator J. B. Dibrell also supported the bill. There was opposition, but the bill was approved and signed by Governor [[Joseph D. Sayers]] on May 10, 1899.{{cite web |url=http://ecommons.txstate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1002&context=jamcfacp |title=Fifty Years of Teacher Education: A Brief History of Southwest Texas State Teachers College, San Marcos, Texas, 1901-1951 |publisher= Journalism and Mass Communication, School of |accessdate=April 15, 2010}} Previously, teachers were required to study at Coronal Institute at San Marcos or North Texas Normal School at Denton. Upon passage of the bill, citizens of San Marcos allocated {{convert|11|acre|m2}} at the site of Chautauqua Hill for the site of the college. [[Old Main (Texas State University)|Old Main]] was not constructed until the twenty seventh legislature rationed out $25,000 for the upbringing of a facility. Once completed, the school opened its doors with an enrollment of 303, a faculty of seventeen, and a principal on September 9, 1903.{{cite web |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/TT/kct56.html |title=TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITYâSAN MARCOS |publisher=Texas State Handbook Online |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It took 15 years for the school to become a senior college; in response, the name of the school was changed to '''Southwest Texas State Normal College'''. A similar name change, '''Southwest Texas State Teachers College''', was observed in 1923 when the college was admitted into the American Association of Teachers Colleges. President John G. Flowers, in 1950, made a sizable step toward the university's overall goal which included a boost in curriculum and an addition of six new buildings. By this time, campus grounds had grown from {{convert|11|acre|m2}} to sixty five, faculty numbers were at an all-time high of 105, the campus had a 3.5 million dollar property value, and the college had an enrollment of 2,000. [[Image:HigherEduPlaque.jpg|right|thumb|[[Higher Education Act of 1965|Higher Education Act]] signing plaque rests in front of the College of Music.]] The school's next name change did not come until 1959 when it was changed to '''Southwest Texas State College''' and later, '''Southwest Texas State University''', in 1969. The next decade brought the school national recognition when Alumnus [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] claimed the presidency and the school's dance team, the Strutters, performed at his inauguration. Johnson returned to Southwest Texas State Teachers College when he signed the [[Higher Education Act of 1965]], part of the [[Great Society]]. During his 1965 remarks at [[Strahan Coliseum]], Johnson described living in a compact room atop Dr. Evans' garage and working dozens of jobs.{{cite web |url=http://www.lbjlib.utexas.edu/Johnson/lbjforkids/edu_whca370-text.shtm |title=Johnson signs legislation into law |publisher= LBJ Library and Museum |accessdate=October 23, 2009}} In 1996, [[Westwood High School (Austin, Texas)|Westwood High School]], located in [[Williamson County, Texas|Williamson County]], began hosting a number of the university's graduate night classes in Business Administration and Education. Later, a {{convert|101|acre|km2|adj=on}} gift brought the program from a high school to the late constructed [[Round Rock Higher Education Center]] to occupy increasing popularity and employment. The most recent name change took effect in September 2003. Leaders from the university's Associated Student Government (ASG) went to Senator Jeff Wentworth to propose a bill and convince the [[Texas Legislature]] to change the university's name.{{cite press release |url=http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75R/Senate/members/dist25/pr03/p030603a.htm |title=Bill filed today to change Southwest Texas State University's name |date=March 6, 2003 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Overall, the five name changes are: *Southwest Texas State Normal School (1903–1918) *Southwest Texas State Normal College (1918–1923) *Southwest Texas State Teachers College (1923–1959) *Southwest Texas State College (1959–1969) *Southwest Texas State University (1969–2003) *Texas State UniversityâSan Marcos (2003—) ==Campus== [[Image:Elmcreek67.jpg|left|thumb|Campus from 2500 feet]] The campus is located in [[San Marcos, Texas|San Marcos]], a community of nearly 50,000 people about halfway between [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] and [[San Antonio]] on [[Interstate 35 in Texas|Interstate 35]]. Its location on the banks of the [[San Marcos River]] provides students with recreational and leisure activities, such as [[human swimming|swimming]] and [[Tubing (recreation)|tubing]], throughout the year. Texas State's campus today consists of a {{convert|457|acre|km2|sing=on}} main campus and {{convert|4777|acre|km2}} more in recreational, instructional, farm and ranch land. The university operates [[Sewell Park]] which is on the banks of the spring fed [[San Marcos River]]. The banks, part of land leased by the [[U.S. Bureau of Fisheries]], were built up from the river bottom by university workers. Initially named Riverside Park, it was later renamed to Sewell Park in 1946 in honor of Dr. S.M. "Froggy" Sewell, a mathematics professor who helped form the park.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/about/history-traditions/sewell-park.html |title=Sewell Park |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} {{-}} [[Image:ObamaTexasState.jpg|right|thumb|Presidential hopeful [[Barack Obama]] on a campaign stop at [[Sewell Park]]http://www.txstate.edu/about/history-traditions/sewell-park.html]] Just east of the library lies the Quad, a centrally located, tree-lined corridor which bears majority of Texas State's academic colleges.{{cite web |url=http://pride-traditions.ua.txstate.edu/Places/quad.html |title=The Quad |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 8, 2009 }} While walking to class, one may encounter a variety of student organization fundraisers, or attend campus activities including speeches and other various events.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/about/history-traditions/the-quad.html |title=Traditions - Quad |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 8, 2009 }} On campus food services are provided by external company [[Chartwells]] who, in addition to five dining halls, also provides options to franchised chains [[Chick-fil-A]], [[Panda Express]], [[Pizza Hut]], [[Starbucks]], [[Einstein Bros. Bagels]], and Freshens Smoothie Company.{{cite web |url=http://www.dineoncampus.com/txstate/?cmd=menus |title=Chartwells Service |publisher=Chartwells |accessdate=September 26, 2009 }} Texas State formed an agreement with [[Wells Fargo]] to allow students to pair university identification cards with their checking accounts. While this option is not required, it is made convenient through several [[Wells Fargo]] locations on and near campus.{{cite web |url=http://www.auxiliaryservices.txstate.edu/idservices/bobcatcard.html |title=Bobcat Card |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 26, 2009 }} ===Old Main=== {{Main|Old Main (Texas State University)}} Overlooking the campus and serving as a geographic landmark since 1903 is Old Main, a restored red-gabled [[Victorian era|Victorian Gothic]] building. It was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1983.{{cite web |url=http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natregsearchresult.do?fullresult=true&recordid=35 |title=Main Building, Southwest Texas Normal School |publisher=National Register of Historic Places |accessdate=June 5, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In more than a century of use the building has served many uses from being the university's administration building to an auditorium and chapel to now housing the offices for the School of Journalism and Mass Communication as well as the College of Fine Arts.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/about/history-traditions/old-main.html |title=Old Main |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It is often seen as the trademark building for Texas State University, as it is the most highlighted and lit building on campus.{{cite web |url=http://pride-traditions.ua.txstate.edu/Places/old-main/contentParagraph/0/document/Southwestern+Historical+Quarterly,+1974.pdf |title=Southwestern Historical Quarterly |date=April 1974 |publisher=The Texas State Historical Association |accessdate=June 5, 2009 }} ===Alkek Library=== {{Main|Alkek Library}} [[Image:AleckLibrary.JPG|right|thumb|Alkek Library]] The university's library was named, in 1991, for an alumnus who became an oilman, rancher, and philanthropist, Albert B. Alkek. The Albert B. Alkek Library serves as the main, central [[academic library]] supporting the Texas State University community. As a storehouse for [[United States]] and [[Texas]] government documents, the library receives a large number of government publications from the state and 60% of all federal publications. The mission of the library, as stated by University Officials, "is to help our patrons succeed by providing high quality library services and information in a variety of formats to support the university's teaching and research programs."{{cite web |url=http://www.library.txstate.edu/about/about-the-library.html |title=About the Library |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Among the Library's seven floors, students encounter 1.4 million printed texts, over 500,000 microfilm & audio-visual materials, 155,000 electronic books, 300 databases, 97,000 electronic journals, University Archives, and curriculum materials approved by the [[Texas Education Agency]] for primary and secondary schools. In addition to the vast amount of resources, the Library encompasses niche collections which are rare to the University. These holdings include The [[Wittliff collections]] housed on the Library's seventh floor, the King of the Hill archives, major work of significant writers such as [[Cormac McCarthy]] and [[Sam Shepard]], and the Lonesome Dove collection. ===Campus Gallery=== Image:Old Main Txstate.JPG|Old Main Image:Central promenade - TSU San Marcos.jpg|Central Promenade Image:Derrick Hall and Alkek Library - TSU San Marcos.jpg|Derrick Hall Image:Taylor-Murphy.JPG|Taylor-Murphy History Building Image:Bobcatstatue.JPG| Bobcat Statue Image:Fountain in river at TX State Univ., San Marcos, IMG_4094.JPG|Fountain adjacent to J.C. Kellam Administration Building Image:Texas State University at San Marcos sign IMG_4097.JPG|Entrance sign to Texas State University Image:Alkek Library - TSU San Marcos.jpg|Alkek Library ==Residence life== The Department of Housing and Residential Life at Texas State University furnishes students with housing, including 21 on-campus residence halls and four off-campus apartments. As stated on their website, the department aids the university's overall goal to provide students with a well-rounded education by issuing support and sustainability through social and academic affairs.{{cite web |url=http://www.reslife.txstate.edu/about-us/departmental-philosophy.html |title=Residential Life |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=August 26, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Residence Halls at Texas State University include Traditional, Suite, and Super-Suite Style options. Currently, the following options are given to students{{cite web | url=http://www.reslife.txstate.edu/housing-options-and-rates/residence-halls.html | title=Residence Halls | date=August 26, 2009 | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-08-26}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}: *Traditional Style Halls include community restrooms and students typically share a bedroom with another student. Traditional Halls do not come with a private living room. *Super-Suite Style Halls come with a shared bathroom between a select group of residents. These halls give residents, optionally, their own bedroom and the opportunity to share a living room and bathroom with at least one other resident. *University owned apartment complexes. Apartments in these complexes are like at independently owned apartment complex. ==Academics== In addition to 111 undergraduate and 86 masters degrees offerings,{{cite web |url=http://education-portal.com/articles/Texas_State_University_in_San_Marcos,_TX.html |title=Texas State University in San Marcos, TX |publisher=Education Portal |accessdate=April 3, 2009 }} the University offers nine doctorate degrees in the areas of Aquatic Resources, Criminal Justice, Education, Geography, and Physical Therapy.{{cite web |url=http://www.gradcollege.txstate.edu/docs/2009-2011_GCatalog.pdf |title=2009-2011 Graduate Catalog |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 8, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2009/07/CJDoctorate073009.html |title=Texas State launches new doctoral program in criminal justice |publisher=University News Service, Texas State University |date=July 30, 2009 |accessdate=September 8, 2009 }} These programs are under the umbrella of the following nine colleges within the University:{{cite web | url=http://www.txstate.edu/academics.html | title=Texas State University Colleges | date=August 26, 2009 | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-08-26}} ===College of Applied Arts=== The College of Applied Arts at Texas State University encompasses seven academic areas in which students can choose to study. Jaime Chahin manages the College as [[Dean (education)|Dean]].{{cite web | url=http://www.appliedarts.txstate.edu/about/Welcom-from-the-Dean.html | title= Message from the Dean | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} The College's Child Development Center, accredited by the national Association for the Education of Young Children(NAEYC), carries the San Marcos Early Childhood Collaboration Project, one out of the three model programs for public child care in state of [[Texas]].{{cite web | url=http://www.appliedarts.txstate.edu/about/Our-Reputation.html | title= Our Reputation | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} Since graduating in 1979, George Strait has initiated an endowment to assist the college's Department of Agriculture giving it the largest scholarship endowment of any department at Texas State. The fields of academic work housed within the College of Applied Arts are: *AeroSpace Studies (AFROTC) *Agriculture *Criminal Justice *Family and Consumer Sciences *Military Science (Army ROTC) *Occupational Education Program *School of Social Work ===Emmett and Miriam McCoy College of Business Administration=== {{Main| McCoy College of Business}} The McCoy College of Business Administration, founded in 1968, is an Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) accredited business program, headquartered in McCoy Hall located just west of Alkek Library on Texas State's campus.{{cite web | url=http://texas.stateuniversity.com/sub/McCoy-College-of-Business-Administration.html#ixzz0RIHvjNLw | title= McCoy College of Business Administration | publisher=stateuniversity.com | accessdate=2009-09-16}} Dr. Denise T. Smart heads McCoy College as [[Dean (education)|Dean]]. While majority of business students take classes in [[San Marcos, Texas|San Marcos]], students have the option of taking a select group of courses at The [[Round Rock Higher Education Center]]. To keep curriculum a balance between real world application and general education, McCoy College maintains a College Advisory Board. Members include [[Senior management|Executive]] level employees ranging from [[Proprietor]]s to [[Chief Executive Officer]]s.{{cite web | url=http://www.business.txstate.edu/McCoy/advisory.htm | title= McCoy Advisory Board | publisher=Texas State University| accessdate=2009-09-16}} McCoy Hall finished construction and was dedicated in 2006. Funding for the facility was achieved primarily through a generous $20 million dollar donation from Emmet and Miriam McCoy, thus coining the name for the college. The endowment, now administered by the McCoy College of Business Development Foundation, provides distinguished professorships, scholarships to both undergraduates and graduates, and program development.{{cite web | url=http://www.business.txstate.edu/McCoy/employment.htm | title= McCoy Advisory Board | publisher=Texas State University| accessdate=2009-10-24}} Later, the McCoy's were awarded [[honorary doctorates]], being the seventh and eighth individuals receiving such awards from Texas State University.{{cite web | url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2007/11/McCoyDoctorate111507.htm | title= McCoy's gain honorary doctorate | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} The College contains five departments{{cite web | url=http://www.business.txstate.edu/McCoy/contact.htm | title=McCoy Hall Dept. and Contact Information | publisher=Texas State University| accessdate=2009-09-16}}: *Department of Accounting *Department of CIS & QMST *Department of Marketing *Department of Management *Department of Finance and Economics ===College of Education=== Texas State's College of Education exists to better prepare students entering careers within the Education Field. Dr. E. Stanley Carpenter is the current Dean of the College.{{cite web | url=http://www.education.txstate.edu/about/deans-message.html | title= Dean's Message | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2011-05-31}} Like the McCoy College of Business Administration, students primarily attend classes at Texas State's main campus is San Marcos, though a growing number are taking them at the Round Rock Higher Education Center. President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] is rooted in the College of Education; he enrolled, what was then Southwest Texas State Teachers' College, in 1926 and graduated with a B. Ed in 1931.{{cite web | url=http://www.education.txstate.edu/about/History-Facts.html | title= History | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} The three areas of study held within the College of Education are{{cite web | url=http://www.education.txstate.edu/departments.html | title= Departments | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}}: *Curriculum and Instruction (CI) *Educational Administration and Psychological Services (EAPS) *Health and Human Performance (HHP) ===College of Fine Arts and Communication=== [[Image:TX State Univ. Theater Center IMG 4089.JPG|200px|right|thumb|Texas State University Theatre Center]] The College of Fine Arts and Communication at Texas State University, led by Dean T. Richard Cheatham,{{cite web | url=http://www.finearts.txstate.edu/ | title=college of fine arts | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} comprises The School of Music, the School of Art and Design, and the School of Journalism and Mass Communication. When choosing an undergraduate degree, students have an option of pursuing a [[Bachelor of Arts]], [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]], or a [[Bachelor of Music]], as well as a Master of Fine arts in: Theatre History, Dramaturgy, Directing, or Playwriting. To this day, Texas State remains the only University in the southwest United States to offer a baccalaureate degree in Sound Recording Technology. The College also claims 17% of the entire University enrollment, and is one of the top Colleges within the University to grant degrees to Hispanics.{{cite web | url=http://www.finearts.txstate.edu/about/College-Overview.html | title=college overview | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} Some of the College's more notable faculty include [[Kaitlin Hopkins]] and [[Lauren Lane]]. The Sound Recording Technology program was founded to the School of Music by the university when Fire Station Studios was purchased 1992. Within the three schools lie two other departments: *Communication Studies *Theatre & Dance ===College of Health Professions=== Conducted by Dean Ruth B. Welborn, Texas State University's College of Health Professions equips students with the knowledge needed for today's careers in the health care industry. Additionally, a central goal of the College is to help improve the overall perception of health care.{{cite web | url=http://www.health.txstate.edu/About/Overview.html | title=college overview | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} Through its nine departments and six undergraduate degree programs,{{cite web | url=http://www.health.txstate.edu/Degrees-Programs/Undergraduate-Degree-Programs.html | title=undergraduate degree programs | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} the College offers technical, clinical, professional and academic programs. Construction of the St. David's School of Nursing started in 2008 after St. David's Community Health Foundation announced a $6 million donation in November 2006.{{cite web | url=http://www.stdavidsfoundation.org/news_nursingschool.htm | title=St. David's School of Nursing at Texas State University | publisher=StDavids.com | accessdate=2009-09-16}} The school is scheduled to open in time for Fall 2010 classes.{{cite web | url=http://star.txstate.edu/content/school-nursing-round-rock-prepares-applications | title=School Of Nursing At Round Rock Prepares For Applications | publisher=ustar.txstate.edu | accessdate=2010-05-15}} Departments within the College include{{cite web | url=http://www.health.txstate.edu/departments.html | title=Departments | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}}: *Clinical Laboratory Science *Health Administration *Health Information Management *St. David's School of Nursing *Physical & Radiation Therapy *Respiratory Care *Texas Long Term Care Institute ===College of Liberal Arts=== The College of Liberal Arts is housed within Flowers Hall and made up of 5,114 students, taught by 28% of the University's faculty, who are pursuing degrees offered in the College's nine departments, eight inner-located programs, and four interdisciplinary centers.{{cite web | url=http://www.liberalarts.txstate.edu/about/deans-message.html | title=Dean's Message | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} The faculty within the College include many who have won prestigious, national awards. Included are eight Fulbright Scholars, eight Piper Professors, and 14 recipients of the National Council for Geographic Education's Distinguished Teaching Achievement Award.{{cite web | url=http://www.liberalarts.txstate.edu/about/overview.html | title=Overview Liberal Arts | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} While it is not a requirement, the Liberal Arts College encourages and offers several [[study abroad]] programs in locations such as Belize, England, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Spain, and Switzerland. The [[Association of American Geographers]] and the [[Journal of Geography]] consistently rank Texas State's Department of Geography among the best in the nation.{{cite web | url=http://www.geo.txstate.edu/about/history.html | title=Geography History | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2009-09-16}} The College also claims a handful of the faculty within the Creative Writing program, of which include: *[[Tim O'Brien (author)|Tim O'Brien]] author and holder of the endowed chair in the MFA Creative Writing program{{cite web |url=http://www.mfatxstate.com/chair.asp |title=Endowed Chair |publisher=Texas State University MFA Dept |accessdate=September 16, 2009 }} *[[Roger Jones (poet)|Roger Jones]] poet and professor in the MFA Creative Writing program *[[Kathleen Peirce]] poet and professor in the MFA Creative Writing program *[[Cyrus Cassells]] poet and professor in the MFA Creative Writing program The College's departments include:{{cite web | url=http://www.geo.txstate.edu/about/history.html | title=Departments and Research Centers | publisher=Texas State University | accessdate=2011-02-25}} *Anthropology *English *Geography *History *International Studies *Modern Languages *Philosophy *Political Science *Psychology *Sociology ===College of Science and Engineering=== The College of Science is led by Dean Stephen Seidman, consists of 185 faculty and claims roughly 11% of the student body. In 2003, the Ingram School of Engineering was established while funding for the program was later achieved primarily through a 5 million dollar donation from Bruce and Gloria Ingram. According to Dr. Stephen Seidman, dean of the college, the college is unique in that it encourages students to get involved with faculty research. Along with the Ingram School of Engineering, the College of Science houses the following departments{{cite web |url=http://www.science.txstate.edu/about/deans-welcome.html |title=Dean of College of Science's Message |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=January 24, 2010 }} : *Biology *Chemistry & Biochemistry *Computer Science *Engineering Technology *Mathematics *Physics ===University College=== The University College, previously known as the College of General Studies, is a college designed for students with undecided majors. It also houses the University Honors Program.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/ucollege/ |title=University College|publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 15, 2010 }} ===Graduate College=== The Graduate College was approved by the Board of Regents in 1935. Named the Graduate School, the name changed to the Graduate Studies and Research school in 1981, then to the Graduate School in 1999.{{cite web |url=http://www.gradcollege.txstate.edu/About/GC_History.html |title=Dean of College of Science's Message |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=January 24, 2010 }} The Graduate College coordinates advanced degrees across all colleges and departments and serves as an administrative hub for graduate and doctoral students throughout the university. ===Admissions=== Texas State University admits roughly 74 percent of applicants.{{cite web | url=http://collegesearch.collegeboard.com/search/CollegeDetail.jsp?collegeId=2241&profileId=1 | title=Texas State University Admissions | date=August 26, 2009 | publisher=College Board | accessdate=2009-08-26}} For admission at Texas State, prospective students must, along with an application, submit required essays and [[SAT]] or [[ACT (test)|ACT]] scores. Class rank may also determine one's acceptance. ==Students== [[Image:Student Center TxState.JPG|right|thumb|LBJ Student Center]] Texas State had an official total student enrollment of 34,113 for the 2011 fall semester; approximately 29,000 of them were undergraduate-level students.. Texas State had an average freshman retention rate of 75.2% from 2003 to 2006, placing the school in the top half of Western schools surveyed by US News and World Report.{{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/college/masters-west-freshmen-least-most-likely-return |title=Best Colleges: Average Freshmen Retention Rates: Master's Universities (West) |publisher=US News and World Report |accessdate=April 4, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The university has been recognized for having a higher graduating rate of Hispanic students compared to similar schools{{Cite news |url=http://www.aascu.org/media/public_purpose/08_0203aossey.pdf |title=Study Finds Keys to Hispanic Student Success |first=Carole |last=Shelley Yates |magazine=Public Purpose |date=February/March 2008 |pages=10â12 |publisher=American Association of State Colleges and Universities |accessdate=April 4, 2009 |postscript= }} where Hispanic students made up 25% of the student population as of 2010.{{cite press release |url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2011/March-2011/HSIRelease032411.html |title=Texas State recognized as Hispanic Serving Institution |date=March 24, 2011 |publisher=University News Service |accessdate=May 31, 2011 }} Texas State has more than 250 student organizations within the categories of Academic, Chartered, Greek, Honors, Multicultural, Political, Professional, Recreational, Religious, Residence Halls, Service, Special Interest and Sports Clubs. The Greek community at Texas State includes a variety of service, traditions, and leadership. There are 31 organizations and more than 1,300 students who are members. Campus student-politics include the school's Associated Student Government, headed by the ASG President and Vice President. Along with the Executive Branch the ASG Senate, a Supreme Court, and the Graduate House of Representatives also make up the Associated Student Government. Students have the option of utilizing the Student Recreation Center (SRC) at Texas State. A newly renovated extension, completed and dedicated in early 2009, added a rock wall, a [[natatorium]] with many indoor pools, additional cardio machines, a designated free weights room, workout studios, new locker rooms, a small scale computer lab, and a [[chartwells]] cafe.{{cite web |url=http://www.campusrecreation.txstate.edu/programs/informal/facility-descriptions.html |title=Campus Recreation |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 26, 2009 }} Texas State has an active Greek System which encompasses the [[National Panhellenic Conference|Panhellenic Council]], the [[National Multicultural Greek Council]], the [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]] and the [[Order of Omega]] with over 30 different [[fraternities and sororities]]. Active chapters include: {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" !colspan=3|Interfraternity Council{{cite web|url=http://txstateifc.theginsystem.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=27 |title=TxST Interfraternity Council - Fraternities |accessdate=2009-10-19}} !colspan=2|National Pan-Hellenic Council{{cite web|url=http://www.studentorgs.txstate.edu/nphc/ |title=TxST National Pan-Hellenic Council |accessdate=2009-10-19}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} !colspan=2|Pan-Hellenic Council{{cite web|url=http://www.txstatepanhellenic.com/page.php?page_id=5509 |title=TxST Pan-Hellenic Council |accessdate=2009-10-19}} |- |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| *[[Alpha Tau Omega]] *[[Delta Tau Delta]] *[[Omega Delta Phi]] *[[Kappa Alpha Order]] *[[Kappa Sigma]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| *[[Phi Delta Theta]] *[[Phi Kappa Psi]] *[[Pi Kappa Alpha]] *[[Pi Kappa Phi]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| *[[Sigma Chi]] *[[Sigma Nu]] *[[Sigma Tau Gamma]] *[[Lambda Chi Alpha]] *[[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| *[[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] *[[Alpha Phi Alpha]] *[[Delta Sigma Theta]] *[[Kappa Alpha Psi]] *[[Omega Psi Phi]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| *[[Phi Beta Sigma]] *[[Sigma Gamma Rho]] *[[Zeta Phi Beta]] *[[Iota Phi Theta]] |valign="top" style="font-size:smaller;"| *[[Chi Omega]] *[[Alpha Xi Delta]] *[[Delta Gamma]] *[[Delta Zeta]] *[[Alpha Delta Pi]] *[[Zeta Tau Alpha]] |} ===Student media=== Three times a week, [[University Star|''The University Star'']], Texas Stateâs student newspaper, publishes coverage of the collegeâs news, trends, opinions and sports. The newspaper, located in the Trinity Building, has a distribution of 8,000 in the fall and spring semesters, and is on stands Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.{{cite web |url=http://www.mondonewspapers.com/usa/texas.html |title=Texas Newspapers |publisher=MondoNewspapers |accessdate=August 4, 2010 }} The paper is produced five times during the summer, and has a distribution of 3,000 copies. The ''Star'' is online at www.universitystar.com, where there are videos, blogs and podcasts in addition to the regular content. The Star and its staff have received awards including merits from Hearst Journalism, the Texas Intercollegiate Press Association and the [[Society of Professional Journalists]].{{cite web |url=http://www.universitystar.com |title=University Star |publisher=University Star |accessdate=August 3, 2010}} Located in Old Main, Texas State's [[Frequency modulation|FM]] radio station, [[KTSW]], broadcasts at 89.9 MHz and provides sports coverage of Texas State athletics and indie/[[independent music]]. The KTSW website provides live-streaming broadcasts, and the Texas State television channel employs KTSW broadcasts as background music. KTSW's morning show, ''Orange Juice and Biscuits'', gained recognition in 2007 for being a finalist in Collegiate Broadcasters Inc.'s "Best Regularly Scheduled Program" award and again in October 2008, as it was among [[Austin360.com]]'s top ten-rated morning radio shows.{{cite press release |url=http://www.txstate.edu/news/news_releases/news_archive/2008/10/OrangeJuice100708.html |title=KTSW morning show makes waves in Austin 360 poll |date=October 7, 2008 |first=Lauren |last=Lamb |publisher=University News Service |accessdate=September 15, 2009 }} ===Campus PD=== The university was featured in the [[G4 (TV channel)|G4]]'s TV series [[Campus PD]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/tvblog/entries/2009/11/19/g4s_campus_pd_will_feature_san_marcos.html|title=G4âs âCampus PDâ will feature San Marcos}}. ==Spirit and traditions== [[Image:StruttersTXST.JPG|right|thumb|150px|Texas State Strutters]] The Soap Box Derby has been an annual event since 1967 and is currently hosted by the Order of Omega. During homecoming week, participants race derby cars down Bobcat Trail. Participants are divided into three brackets: Student Organizations, Greeks and Residence Halls.{{cite web |url=http://pride-traditions.ua.txstate.edu/Events/soap-box-derby.html |title=Soap Box Derby |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=June 24, 2009 }} Following each Fall and Spring semester, there is a ring ceremony that seniors are invited to, along with their friends and families. During the ceremony, the senior is presented with their school ring. The student then dips the ring in a fountain containing the waters of the San Marcos River.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstate.edu/about/history-traditions/ring-ceremony.html |title=Ring Ceremony |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 16, 2009 }} Created in 1960, the Texas State Strutters are the oldest dance team in any major Texas university. They are internationally recognized, and have performed in 22 countries in four continents. They have also performed in various sports venues throughout Texas and the United States as well as two presidential inaugurations and five feature films. The group has over 3,000 alumnae and is currently the largest drill team in the nation.{{cite web|url=http://www.txstate.edu/about/history-traditions/strutters.html |title=Strutters |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=July 15, 2009 }} Tradition holds the Theatre building is haunted by a Ghost named Ramseyhttp://www.centexghost.org/html/hays006.html. In honor of this spirit Alpha Psi Omega the Honor Theatre Fraternity gives Ramsey Awards for (their version of the Tonyâs) for the yearly production seasonhttp://www.theatreanddance.txstate.edu/TH-Orgs/APO.html. ==Athletics== {{Main|Texas State Bobcats}} [[File:Texas State Bobcat.PNG|thumb|right|Texas State Bobcats logo]] Teams at Texas State compete at the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] level and are members of the [[Southland Conference]] .{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/conference?confId=30 |title=Southland Conference |publisher=ESPN |accessdate=April 4, 2009 }} The university's football team currently competes as a Division I-FCS independent and does not qualify for postseason play with the [[Southland Conference]]. The football team will begin its transition to the [[Football Bowl Subdivision]] in 2012 as it moves to the [[Western Athletic Conference]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.sanmarcosmercury.com/archives/1399 |title=Texas State receives big boost for big-time football |first= Bill |last=Peterson |publisher=San Marcos Mercury |date=June 27, 2008 |accessdate=April 4, 2009 }} A number of championships have been won including two NCAA Division II football championships, in 1981 and 1982, an NCAA Division II men's golf championship in 1983, and two Southland Conference championships in 2005 and 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstatebobcats.com/ot/txst-championships.html |title=Championships |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=April 4, 2009 }} ===Mascot and Logo=== In 1920, Texas State adopted its first official mascot, the Bobcat, at the urging of Oscar Strahan, who became the school's athletic director in 1919. Strahan suggested the Bobcat because the cat is native to central Texas and is known for its fierceness. The Bobcat didn't get a name until 1964. At that time, Beth Greenless won the "Name the Bobcat" contest with the name Boko the Bobcat.{{cite web |url=http://www.athletics.txstate.edu/spirit/history.htm |title=Boko's History |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=April 4, 2009 }} In 2003, the Bobcat logo was designed by a Texas State student.{{cite web |url=http://pride-traditions.ua.txstate.edu/campus-traditions/logo.html |title=Bobcat Logo |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} In August 2009, Texas State administrators refined its athletic mark by changing the font and placement of the SuperCat.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstatebobcats.com/genrel/081209aac.html |title=Texas State Refines Athletics Mark |date=August 12, 2009 |publisher=TxStateBobcats.com |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} ===Rivalries=== With the intentions to increase fans and numbers at games, Texas State University formed rivalries with various schools including The [[University of Texas at San Antonio]] and [[Nicholls State University]]. Texas State and The [[University of Texas at San Antonio]] originally started this rivalry competing in basketball with hopes of bringing attention to central Texas sports along the I-35 corridor. In the 2007-2008 season, the series was expanded to an "all sport competition." {{cite web |url=http://pride-traditions.ua.txstate.edu/campus-traditions/i-35-rivalry.html |title=I-35 Maroon vs Orange Rivalry Series |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} [[File:Bobcat Stadium West Side.jpg|thumb|right|Fields West Side Complex at Bobcat Stadium completed in 2009]] Annually, Bobcats and the Colonels face off in the Battle for the Paddle Rivalry game. While preparing for a football game against the [[Nicholls State University]] Colonels, a flood struck San Marcos soaking the Bobcat Stadium field. Together, Athletic Directors and coaches chose to continue the game, thus, the name "Battle for the Paddle" was coined.{{cite web |url=http://pride-traditions.ua.txstate.edu/campus-traditions/battle-for-the-paddle.html |title=Battle for the Paddle |publisher=Texas State University |accessdate=September 21, 2011}} ===Transition to FBS=== With the continuing support for Texas State Athletics, there was an effort to promote the football team to Division I-FBS competition, the [[Football Bowl Subdivision#Football Bowl Subdivision|Football Bowl Subdivision]]. A student referendum was proposed on November 2007 and approved by the student body on April 2008. That referendum starting a move, dubbed âThe Drive to FBS,â and has led to the renovation of athletic facilities, including construction of new baseball and softball stadiums and expansion of [[Bobcat Stadium (Texas State)|Bobcat Stadium]]. Texas State's first 2009 season football game against [[Angelo State University]] opened '''The Jerry D. and Linda Gregg Fields Bobcat Stadium West Side Complex''' encompassing Club and Luxury level seating.{{cite web |url=http://www.txstatebobcats.com/facilities/bobcat-stadium-west-side-complex.html |title=Jerry D. and Linda Gregg Fields Bobcat Stadium West Side Complex |publisher=TexasStateBobcats.com |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} Because Athletics Director Larry Teis stated the next phase in renovating Bobcat Stadium cannot begin until the stadium's track is relocated, the university broke ground on a new Track and Field Complex with land purchased by the university behind [[Bobcat Stadium (Texas State)|Bobcat Stadium]]. Completion of the Track and Field Complex is expected Summer 2011. In May 2011, Texas State began construction connecting the east and west sides at [[Bobcat Stadium (Texas State)|Bobcat Stadium]]. Completion is expected in time for Texas Stateâs first home 2012 football game against [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech]]. Recent athletic fee raises are helping fund the renovations. On November 11, 2010, it was announced that Texas State would be joining the [[University of Denver]] and the [[University of Texas at San Antonio]] in the [[Western Athletic Conference]] (WAC) beginning July 1, 2012.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/news/story?id=5789078 |title=Sources: Denver University, Texas-San Antonio and Texas State to join WAC |publisher=ESPN |first=Andy |last=Katz |date=November 10, 2010 |accessdate=November 11, 2010}} ==Alumni== {{Main|List of Texas State UniversityâSan Marcos alumni}} [[Image:SmilingLBJ.jpg|right|thumb|150px|[[Lyndon B.
